questions.text: Which of the following anti rheumatoid drug increases extracellular adenosine? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methotrexate

 

Methotrexate works primarily by inhibiting AICAR transformylase and thymidylate synthetase.

 

AICAR accumulates intracellularly and competes with AMP deaminase, resulting in AMP accumulation. AMP is released and converted extracellularly to adenosine, which is acts as the powerful anti-inflammatory agent. As a result, neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, and lymphocytes' inflammatory functions are suppressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leflunomide: Leflunomide inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, which is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidines, thereby suppressing the proliferation of activated lymphocytes. It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Option C. Sulphasalazine: Sulphasalazine is a prodrug that is metabolized into sulfapyridine and 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA). Its anti-inflammatory effects are primarily due to the action of 5-ASA. It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Option D. Hydroxychloroquine: Hydroxychloroquine is thought to exert its anti-inflammatory effects by interfering with lysosomal activity and autophagy in immune cells, and by modulating the activity of toll-like receptors (TLRs). It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate increases extracellular adenosine by inhibiting AICAR transformylase, leading to the accumulation of AICAR, which competes with AMP deaminase and causes AMP to accumulate and be converted to adenosine outside the cell, thus exerting anti-inflammatory effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypercalcemia 

 

Tumor lysis syndrome occurs due to destruction of large no of rapidly proliferating neoplstic cells. It is characterised by Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia , hyperphosphasphatemia, hypocalcemia, acidosis, acute renal failure.

 

It mainly occurs after initiation of chemotherapy and is diagnosed by Cairo bishop criteria (includes both lab and clinical features)

 

Management includes - allopurinol , rasburicase along with aggressive hydration .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperphosphatemia: Typically occurs as phosphate is released from lysed tumor cells.

 

Option B. Hyperuricemia: Results from the metabolism of nucleic acids from destroyed cells.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: Occurs due to the release of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space.

 

Educational Objective:


In tumor lysis syndrome, the rapid breakdown of tumor cells leads to hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, making this the key distinguishing feature in identifying the condition. Management strategies like hydration, use of allopurinol, or rasburicase are critical in preventing renal failure and other serious complications.

choices.text: Acute myeloid leukemia with RUNX1 mutation

questions.text: All leukemias come under provisional entity in WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumours except: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B-lymphoblastic leukemia/ lymphoma with hypodiploidy

 

It is not a provisional entity under WHO 2016 Classification of Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tumors.

 

Leukemias that come under provisional entity in WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid are:

 

  1. Myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with PCM1-JAK2
  2. Refractory cytopenia of childhood
  3. AML with BCR-ABL1
  4. AML with mutated RUNX1 (Option C)
  5. B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma, BCR-ABL1–like
  6. B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with iAMP21
  7. Early T-cell precursor lymphoblastic leukemia
  8. Natural killer (NK) cell lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (Option A)
  9. Splenic B-cell lymphoma/leukemia, unclassifiable (Option D)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO 2016 classification introduced several provisional entities in hematolymphoid neoplasms, which are conditions that are newly recognized or still under study for their clinical significance.

 

B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with hypodiploidy is not a provisional entity under the WHO 2016 Classification of Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tumors.

questions.text: The most important marker of male fertility in semen analysis is? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Morphology

 

Explanation:

 

The morphology of sperm is considered the most important marker of male fertility. While sperm concentration and progressive motility are valuable for distinguishing between fertile and infertile men, strict sperm morphology is the most discriminating factor in assessing male fertility potential.

 

Morphological abnormalities in spermatozoa can be identified in various parts, including the head, neck, mid-piece, and tail. These abnormalities can result from defective spermatogenesis or certain epididymal pathologies, leading to increased morphological defects in the sperm. Spermatozoa with abnormal morphology have a lower fertilizing potential, making morphology a critical parameter in semen analysis for determining fertility.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Concentration: Sperm concentration is an important parameter, but it is not as critical as morphology in predicting fertility. The WHO 2021 standard for sperm concentration is 16 million/ml.

 

Option C. Motility: Progressive motility is significant, with the WHO 2021 standard being 30%, but it is not the most crucial parameter compared to morphology.

 

Option D. Sperm Count: While total sperm count is important, it is encompassed under concentration and motility measures. Morphology remains the most critical individual parameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sperm morphology is the most important marker of male fertility in semen analysis, as it directly correlates with the fertilizing potential of the sperm.

 

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg443, https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240030787

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis according to the given image? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoaneurysm of internal carotid artery

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows a digital subtraction angiography of ICA and it shows an outpouching of the contrast suggestive of a pseudoaneurysm of the internal carotid artery as marked by the arrow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF) is the result of an abnormal vascular connection between the internal carotid artery (ICA) and the cavernous sinus. Pulsatile proptosis of eye would be the pathognomic clinical finding. DSA would reveal enlarged draining superior ophthalmic vein.

 

 

Option C. Tumor blush of angiofibroma would show feeder vessels from internal maxillary artery of ECA.

 

Option D. Extensive head and neck hemangioma would show multiple tortuous vessels supplying a mass which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pseudoaneurysm of the internal carotid artery is characterized by an outpouching of contrast material in angiographic studies, as seen in the provided DSA image. This finding is distinct from other vascular abnormalities such as carotid-cavernous fistulas, angiofibromas, or hemangiomas.

questions.text: Which of the following does not happen in 5' to 3' direction?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RNA editing

 

  • RNA editing is not a synthesis process; it involves modification of the pre-existing RNA sequence after transcription.
  • It may include: Base substitution (e.g., A-to-I, C-to-U)
  • Directionality (5′ to 3′) does not apply to these post-transcriptional modifications in the same way it applies to polymerization.
  • An example of RNA editing is apoB gene and mRNA
     

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transcription: Occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, where RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA from a DNA template.

 

Option B. DNA Replication: Occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, with DNA polymerase adding nucleotides to the growing DNA strand.

 

Option C. DNA Repair: DNA repair processes, including nucleotide excision repair and base excision repair, involve synthesis in the 5' to 3' direction during the filling in of repaired regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RNA editing, such as the editing of the apolipoprotein B mRNA, can involve modifications that do not occur in the 5' to 3' direction, unlike transcription, DNA replication, and DNA repair.

questions.text: Identify the blue line shown in the below picture:(AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ohngren's line

 

  • Ohngren's line is an imaginary line passing through the medial canthus of the eye and angle of mandible.
  • It is used for classification of maxillary carcinoma.
  • Growth situated above the plane - Suprastructure - Poor Prognosis
  • Growth situated below the plane - Infrastructure - Good Prognosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frankfurt horizontal line, the line passing through the inferior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal, is one of the most widely used intracranial landmarks in cephalometric analysis.

 

 

Option B. Donaldson line is an imaginary line drawn posteriorly from the course of the horizontal semicircular canal, used to identify endolymphatic sac during endolymphatic sac decompression surgery for meniere’s disease.

 

 

Option C. According to Lederman’s classification, 2 horizontal lines called lines of Sebileau pass through orbit floor and maxillary sinus, producing Suprastructure, mesostructure and infrastructure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ohngren's line is used to classify maxillary carcinomas into suprastructure and infrastructure based on their location relative to the line, which is critical for determining the prognosis and approach for surgical intervention.

questions.text: A patient presents at 18 weeks with low risk of trisomy on quadruple marker and high risk of NTD. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anomaly scan

 

The correct answer is Anomaly scan. This patient has a low risk of trisomy (such as Down syndrome) but a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) based on the quadruple marker test. The quadruple marker test includes measurements of beta-hCG, unconjugated estriol, inhibin A, and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). A high level of AFP is associated with an increased risk of NTDs, such as spina bifida.

 

Given the elevated risk for NTDs, the most appropriate next step is an anomaly scan, specifically a targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFA) scan. This ultrasound, typically performed between 18 and 20 weeks of gestation, has a high sensitivity (up to 99%) for detecting structural anomalies, particularly neural tube defects. The scan is a non-invasive way to assess the fetus for physical defects.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Amniocentesis: While amniocentesis can detect chromosomal abnormalities and some structural defects, it is invasive and carries a small risk of complications. Since the concern here is structural (NTD) rather than chromosomal, and the anomaly scan is highly effective and non-invasive, amniocentesis is not the first choice.

 

Option C. Chorionic villous sampling (CVS): CVS is another invasive procedure used for early genetic testing, usually performed in the first trimester. It is not useful at 18 weeks and is not the best test for detecting structural anomalies like NTDs.

 

Option D. NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing): NIPT is a screening tool for chromosomal aneuploidies (like trisomy 21, 18, and 13). Since the patient already has a low risk of trisomy, NIPT is unnecessary and does not address the high risk of NTD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a high risk of neural tube defects identified by elevated alpha-fetoprotein on a quadruple marker test, the best next step is an anomaly scan (TIFA), which is highly effective in identifying structural fetal abnormalities, including NTDs

questions.text: What is the appropriate BIRADS category for a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BIRADS 2

 

BIRADS 2 is used for benign findings. Given that the histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, which is a well-recognized benign breast condition, BIRADS 2 is the most suitable category for this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BIRADS 1 or 2: BIRADS 1 is assigned to a category when there is no suspicion of malignancy, and BIRADS 2 is used when there is a benign finding. In this case, since the histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, which is a benign breast condition, BIRADS 2 is the most appropriate category.

 

Option B. BIRADS 2 or 4: BIRADS 4 is used when there is a suspicious abnormality that may or may not be cancerous. Since the histology in this case indicates a fibroadenoma appearance, which is benign, BIRADS 4 would not be appropriate.

 

Option C. BIRADS 2, 3, or 4: BIRADS 3 is assigned when there is a probably benign finding that requires short-term follow-up. In this case, since the histology indicates a fibroadenoma appearance (a benign finding), BIRADS 3 and BIRADS 4 would not be applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, the appropriate BIRADS category is BIRADS 2.

 

Fibroadenoma is a benign tumor that poses a low risk of malignancy. The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) categories are used to assess the likelihood of malignancy of breast lesions seen on mammograms, ultrasounds, or MRI. Grades 1 and 2 have a very low probability of being malignant, while grade 3 has a slightly higher probability of malignancy.

 

Grades 4 and 5 are considered suspicious and warrant further investigation as they have a higher probability of malignancy.

choices.text: Pathergy test is a criterion as per the ISG diagnostic criteria
Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis
Aphthous ulcers occur similar to Crohn’s disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding Behçet's disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis

 

Behçet's disease is a chronic, multisystem vasculitis characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, ocular inflammation, skin lesions, and more. Genital ulcers in Behçet's typically occur on the scrotum in males and the vulva in females. The dorsum of the penis is rarely involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathergy test is a criterion as per the ISG diagnostic criteria: Correct. The International Study Group (ISG) includes the pathergy test (a sterile pustule at the site of needle prick) as a supportive criterion.

 

Option C. Aphthous ulcers occur similar to Crohn’s disease: Correct. The oral ulcers of Behçet’s resemble aphthous ulcers and can be clinically indistinguishable from those seen in Crohn’s disease.

 

Option D. Bilateral pan uveitis: Correct. Ocular involvement is common and may present as anterior uveitis, posterior uveitis, or pan uveitis—often bilateral and sight-threatening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Behçet’s disease typically affects the scrotum, vulva, eyes, and oral mucosa. Ulcers on the dorsum of the penis are atypical, making option B the incorrect statement.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a male patient in his early twenties who presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of abdominal pain and obstipation, and reports blunt injury to the abdomen 3 days prior? The provided X-ray image may provide clues to the diagnosis: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • The given radiograph in the erect position indicates air under the diaphragm, which is a typical finding in cases of hollow viscus perforation.
  • A history of trauma, accompanied by symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation, supports the diagnosis of a perforation of the alimentary tract.

 

A perforation of a hollow organ (like the intestines or stomach) can lead to air and contents of the organ leaking into the abdominal cavity. It can be a result of trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemothorax: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of blood within the pleural cavity, often due to trauma. The patient's symptoms are abdominal in nature and not respiratory, making this an unlikely diagnosis. Hemothorax would be evident on a chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: This is the presence of air in the pleural cavity, often due to trauma or a spontaneous event, leading to lung collapse. Similar to hemothorax, this condition is related to the respiratory system and would not be the cause of abdominal pain or obstipation.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: This condition involves a blockage that prevents the contents of the intestines from passing normally through the digestive tract. However, no free air should be seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation can cause acute bacterial peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum that can be localized or generalized.
  • Clinical features of peritonitis include abdominal pain that worsens with movement, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, and guarding on palpation. Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.
  • An erect abdominal radiograph that shows free gas under the diaphragm.
  • Management of peritonitis involves general care of the patient in terms of nutritional support and pain relief. Laparotomy and surgical treatment of the cause is usually necessary.

questions.text: A male patient complained of bone and joint pain and was prescribed NSAIDs. After a few days, he returned with vesiculo-bullous lesions that subsequently healed, leaving a brownish discoloration on his face (particularly in the upper lip area), as shown in the image. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fixed drug eruption

 

The given clinical situation suggests a diagnosis of a Fixed drug eruption. Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common forms of drug induced exanthems.

 

A fixed drug eruption is a known adverse drug reaction characterized by recurrent skin eruptions at the same location upon re-exposure to a specific drug. The vesiculo-bullous lesions followed by brownish discoloration can be seen in fixed drug eruptions, making it the most likely diagnosis given the patient's history of NSAID use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the Plasmodium parasite, which is transmitted to humans via the bites of infected Anopheles mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: Fever (often cyclic), chills, sweating, headaches, muscle pains, fatigue, anemia, jaundice due to hemolysis, and enlargement of the spleen.
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: Malaria does not typically cause vesico-bullous lesions or discoloration of the face.

 

Option B. Dengue:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the dengue virus, which is transmitted through the bite of Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: High fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, rash, and mild bleeding (e.g., nose or gum bleed, or easy bruising).
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: While dengue can cause rashes, it does not usually result in vesico-bullous lesions or leave a persistent brownish discoloration on the skin.

 

Option C. Chikungunya fever:

 

A strong differential diagnosis is post chikungunya pigmentation (PCP) of the face seen on the nose & cheeks (Chik Sign) as shown in the below image.

 

 

Why it's not the likely diagnosis: However, this is not the answer because there is no antecedent history of fever, myalgia, or other symptoms suggestive of chikungunya. PCP often appears as the fever subsides and may persist for about three to six months. PCP mimics melasma & may be misdiagnosed If proper history is not taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE)

 

FDE is a drug eruption distinguished by its recurrence at the same sites on re‐challenge with the same drug, hence their site on the skin is fixed, it has a short latency and is benign in nature.

 

FDE typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.

 

  • Typically, FDE presents as a sharply‐defined, round or oval erythematous and edematous plaque which evolves to become dusky, violaceous and occasionally vesicular or bullous.
  • Classically hyperpigmentation occurs after lesions heal. Most common cause:
    • NSAIDs - On Lips
    • Cotrimoxazole - On Genitals

 

Acute onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAID's are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 118 page no 118.11, 118.12

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition pages 141-142, 1633

choices.text: Teratozoospermia
Asthenozoospermia
Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

questions.text: The results of semen analysis of a young male have been given below. What is the diagnosis? 5 million/mI concentration, 50% motility, 4% normal morphology? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oligospermia

 

Explanation:

 

The given semen analysis results show a sperm concentration of 5 million/mL, which is below the normal reference value set by the WHO. According to the WHO 2021 guidelines, a normal sperm concentration is 16 million/mL or higher. Therefore, this patient has oligospermia, which is defined as a sperm concentration of less than 15 million/mL. Counts below 5 million/mL are considered severe.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Oligospermia: Sperm concentration <15 million/mL. Severe oligospermia is when counts are <5 million/mL.
  • Teratozoospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology.
  • Asthenozoospermia: No motile sperms or diminished motility.
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: A combination of low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teratozoospermia: Teratozoospermia refers to abnormal sperm morphology. The morphology here is 4%, which is within the normal range according to WHO criteria.

 

Option C. Asthenozoospermia: Asthenozoospermia refers to reduced sperm motility. In this case, the motility is 50%, which is normal.

 

Option D. Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: This term describes a condition where there is a combination of low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology. In this case, only the sperm concentration is abnormal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of less than 15 million/mL, with counts below 5 million/mL considered severe. The given semen analysis results show oligospermia based on the sperm concentration of 5 million/mL.

 

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 442, Duttas textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg232

https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240030787

questions.text: Which of the following is gametocidal to all the species causing malaria? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Primaquine

 

Primaquine is gametocidal to all species causing malaria. It inhibits transmission of malaria. Artemisinin also have high gametocidal activity against all the species.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • Primaquine interferes with the mitochondrial electron transport chain in the parasite, leading to the death of gametocytes and hypnozoites (dormant liver forms in Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale).
  • By eliminating gametocytes, primaquine helps reduce the spread of malaria within a community.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloroquine: is primarily effective against the erythrocytic forms of Plasmodium species but does not have gametocidal activity against all species. It is not effective against the dormant liver forms or the gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Option C. Quinine: is effective against the asexual blood stages of Plasmodium species but lacks significant activity against the gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum. It does not have a broad gametocidal effect against all species.

 

Educational Objective

 

Primaquine is the antimalarial drug that is gametocidal to all Plasmodium species, making it essential for preventing the transmission of malaria and addressing relapses in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale infections.

choices.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.text: The rise in blood pressure that occurs at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is a result of? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

 

Valsalva maneuver can lead to a temporary increase in blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system. This phenomenon can be explained by:

 

  • Increased Intrathoracic Pressure: By trying to exhale against a closed airway, you create increased pressure within your chest cavity. This can compress the large blood vessels.
  • Increased Sympathetic Activity: The increased intrathoracic pressure triggers the body’s sympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for the “fight or flight” response. This leads to the release of stress hormones like adrenaline and norepinephrine. These hormones cause blood vessels to constrict (vasoconstriction), which further raises blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure: Incorrect. The pressure increase primarily affects the aorta and systemic circulation, not just the left ventricular pressure.

 

Option C. Increase in left atrial pressure: Incorrect. While there may be a slight increase in left atrial pressure, it is not the primary cause of the rise in blood pressure observed during the Valsalva maneuver.

 

Option D. Increase in left ventricular volume: Incorrect. The maneuver does not directly increase left ventricular volume; instead, it increases pressure within the thoracic cavity affecting the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

The rise in blood pressure at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is primarily due to the increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure, along with increased sympathetic activity.

choices.text: Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure
Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults
Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid leprosy

questions.text: Which among the following is correct regarding the healing of leprosy if left untreated? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Among the given options, Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid is the most appropriate answer

 

The bacillus Mycobacterium leprae is the source of the chronic infectious granulomatous disease known as leprosy (Hansen's disease).

 

Clinically, leprosy can exhibit one or more of the following symptoms

 

  • Patches of hypopigmentation
  • Presence of thickened nerves, and
  • Partial or complete loss of cutaneous sensation in the affected areas (First sensory modality to be lost is Temperature (hot/cold differentiation).
  • The presence of acid-fast bacilli in nasal smears or the skin.

 

Leprosy symptoms vary depending on how an individual's immune system reacts to the bacillus Mycobacterium leprae. Spontaneous resolution can be seen in about 80–90% (NOT just 50% as given in Option B) of people after being exposed to bacteria.  The remaining patients get clinical leprosy. Indeterminate leprosy typically has hypopigmented, ill-defined lesions. 75 percent of those Indeterminate leprosy patients experience spontaneous remission.

 

Clinically, very few patients exhibit either lepromatous leprosy or tuberculoid leprosy. As a result, compared to patients with tuberculoid leprosy, more patients with indeterminate leprosy experience spontaneous remission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No spontaneous remission is seen: Incorrect. Spontaneous remission can occur in leprosy, particularly in the indeterminate and sometimes in the tuberculoid forms due to the individual's immune response.

 

Note - Even in the absence of specific treatment, a majority (80-90%) of patients tend to get cured spontaneously.

 

Option B. Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure. Incorrect. While many individuals may be exposed to Mycobacterium leprae and not develop full-blown leprosy due to a robust immune response, the assertion that half of the cases resolve spontaneously is not accurate. A higher percentage may never progress to clinical disease.

 

Option C. Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spontaneous remission occurs even in the absence of specific treatment in majority (almost 80-90%) of the patients, but when compared to adults, in children spontaneous cure is very much variable.
  • If left untreated, Indeterminate leprosy has a higher rate of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 28.7

Parks textbook of preventive & social medicine 26th edition Pg 359

choices.text: Increased number of theca lutein cysts

questions.text: All of the following can be indicators of choriocarcinoma except: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased number of theca lutein cysts

 

Choriocarcinoma is a malignant form of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) that arises from trophoblastic tissue following a molar pregnancy, miscarriage, abortion, or normal pregnancy. Indicators of choriocarcinoma include:

 

  • Persistently enlarged uterus: Indicates continued trophoblastic proliferation.
  • Plateau of high serum hCG: Persistent high levels of hCG after treatment suggest ongoing trophoblastic disease.
  • Sub-urethral nodule: A rare but specific sign of metastatic choriocarcinoma.

 

The presence of theca lutein cysts alone is not a specific indicator of choriocarcinoma, though these cysts can persist in cases of GTN. The increased number of theca lutein cysts is associated with molar pregnancies and persistent GTN but not specifically indicative of choriocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Persistently enlarged uterus: This is a common finding in choriocarcinoma due to persistent trophoblastic tissue.

 

Option C. Plateau of high serum hCG: This is a hallmark of choriocarcinoma as it indicates continued activity of the trophoblastic cells.

 

Option D. Sub-urethral nodule: This can be a sign of metastasis from choriocarcinoma. Indicates metastasis of choriocarcinoma forming a firm palpable mass beneath urethral nodule

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indicators of choriocarcinoma include persistently enlarged uterus, plateau of high serum hCG, and sub-urethral nodules, but not an increased number of theca lutein cysts alone.

 

Ref: Page no 361, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Craniopagus is defined as the fusion of? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head only

 

Craniopagus refers to a type of conjoined twins where the twins are fused at the cranium (head). This type of conjoined twin fusion involves the skulls but does not typically involve the face or the foramen magnum. Although the brains of craniopagus twins are usually separate, there may be some shared brain tissue, which can sometimes be discovered.

 

Craniopagus twins generally have fused skulls and meninges (the membranes covering the brain), making separation surgeries particularly complex and risky. These twins are genetically identical and are always of the same sex.

 

Craniopagus occurs in approximately 5% of conjoined twin cases, and the prognosis after separation surgery is often poor due to the complexity of the shared structures.

 

Types of Conjoined Twins:

 

  • Abdomen (omphalopagus): Fusion occurs at the abdomen.
  • Chest (thoracopagus): Fusion occurs at the thorax.
  • Top of head down to the belly button, facing each other (cephalopagus): Fusion occurs from the top of the head down to the belly button.
  • Head only (craniopagus): Fusion occurs at the cranium.
  • Pelvis, facing each other (ischiopagus): Fusion occurs at the pelvis with the twins facing each other.
  • Pelvis, side-to-side (parapagus): Fusion occurs at the pelvis with the twins side-by-side.
  • Vertebral column (rachipagus): Fusion occurs at the vertebral column.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head and spine: This type of fusion is not characteristic of craniopagus, which involves only the head.

 

Option C. Thorax and spine: This type of fusion does not apply to craniopagus twins but could describe other forms like thoracopagus or rachipagus.

 

Option D. Thorax only: This describes thoracopagus twins, where the fusion occurs at the thorax, not the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopagus is a specific type of conjoined twins where the fusion occurs only at the cranium (head), and these twins are genetically identical and of the same sex.

questions.text: NCC derivative for cardiac Structure? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conotruncal Septum

 

Neural crest cells (NCCs) contribute to the development of the conotruncal septum in the heart. The conotruncal septum is also known as the spiral septum and is crucial for the proper division of the truncus arteriosus into the aorta and pulmonary trunk. NCCs migrate from the neural tube to contribute to the formation of this septum. Abnormalities in neural crest cell migration can lead to conotruncal defects such as Tetralogy of Fallot, Truncus Arteriosus, and Transposition of Great Vessels.



PEADS  doing DISCO in front of MMM":

P - Parasympathetic ganglion

E - Enteric plexus

A - ANS ganglion

D - Dorsal root ganglion

S - Schwann cell

D - Dentine tissue

S - Sclera

C - Choroid, Conotruncal septum

O - Connective tissue of glands

M - Melanocyte

M - Mesenchymal bone of head & face

M – Meninges

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AV Cushion: Incorrect because the atrioventricular (AV) cushions are primarily derived from the endocardium via epithelial-to-mesenchymal transformation, not from neural crest cells.

 

Option B. Septum primum: Incorrect because the septum primum, which forms part of the interatrial septum, is derived from the dorsal mesocardium and not from neural crest cells.

 

Option C. SA node: Incorrect because the sinoatrial (SA) node, the heart's primary pacemaker, develops from cardiogenic mesoderm, not from neural crest cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural crest cells contribute to the development of the conotruncal septum (spiral septum) in the heart, and abnormalities in neural crest cell migration can lead to various congenital heart defects.

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription has the base sequence 5'GATCTAC3'. What is the base sequence of RNA product? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5'GUAGAUC3'

 

Explanation:

 

You're given the template strand of DNA:


5′–GATCTAC–3′

 

But remember:

 

  • Transcription reads the DNA template in the 3′ → 5′ direction
  • So we must first reverse the strand to get its 3′ → 5′ orientation
    3′–CATAGTC–5′

 

Now, perform complementary base pairing to make the RNA strand (synthesized 5′ to 3′):

 

 

So the RNA product is:


5′–GUAGAUC–3′

 

Educational Objective

 

The complementary base pairing rules are:

 

  • Adenine (A) pairs with Uracil (U) in RNA.
  • Thymine (T) pairs with Adenine (A).
  • Cytosine (C) pairs with Guanine (G).
  • Guanine (G) pairs with Cytosine (C).

 

The RNA product formed during transcription is complementary to the DNA template strand and follows the base-pairing rules with uracil replacing thymine.

questions.text: A farmer presented with history of ingestion of an unknown substance. He had increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and tachycardia. What is the drug of choice for treatment? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Atropine

 

The above clinical scenario suggests organophosphate poisoning.

 

DOC for treatment- Atropine.

 

Though pralidoxime can also be given, but the main drug of choice is Atropine

 

 

SYMPTOMS:

 

 

MANAGEMENT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is used in cases of calcium deficiency or hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is a reactivator of acetylcholinesterase and is used in combination with atropine to treat organophosphate poisoning. However, it is not the primary drug of choice; atropine is.

 

Option D. Obidoxime: Obidoxime is also an acetylcholinesterase reactivator similar to pralidoxime, used in organophosphate poisoning, but not the primary drug of choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of organophosphate poisoning presenting with symptoms like increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and tachycardia, Atropine is the primary drug of choice for treatment. It acts by competitively inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine.

questions.text:
The correct sequence of maturation of sperms in spermatogenesis:

 

  1. Spermatogonia
  2. Spermatocytes
  3. Spermatid
  4. Spermatozoa
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4, 1 

 

The process of spermatogenesis involves the maturation of sperm cells in a specific sequence:

 

2. Spermatogonia: These are the germ cells that divide by mitosis to produce more spermatogonia and primary spermatocytes. This stage marks the beginning of spermatogenesis.

 

3. Spermatocytes: Spermatogonia differentiate into primary spermatocytes, which undergo the first meiotic division to form secondary spermatocytes. The secondary spermatocytes then undergo the second meiotic division to produce spermatids.

 

4. Spermatid: These are the immature sperm cells that are formed after meiosis. They undergo a transformation process called spermiogenesis to become mature spermatozoa.

 

1. Spermatozoa: These are the mature sperm cells that are fully formed and capable of fertilizing an ovum.

 

The entire process of spermatogenesis takes approximately 74 days, and around 300 million sperm are produced daily.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of sperm maturation is Spermatogonia → Spermatocytes → Spermatid → Spermatozoa.

questions.text: Which infection contracted in pregnancy won't be teratogenic?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV 2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV 2) primarily causes genital infections and is not generally teratogenic. It poses risks primarily at delivery if there is an active infection, leading to neonatal herpes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Rubella is highly teratogenic, especially if contracted in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common cause of congenital infections and can result in severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Chicken pox: Chickenpox (Varicella) can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which is teratogenic.

 

Educational objective:

 

Among the listed infections, HSV 2 is not considered teratogenic, although it requires careful management to prevent neonatal transmission during delivery.

choices.text: iii, ii, i, iv, v, vi, vii
i, v, ii, iii, iv, vii, vi
vii, ii, v, i, vi, iii, iv
ii, i, iv, v, vi, iii, vii

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps in the correct sequence for performing the Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique:

 

  1. Apply carbol fuchsin to cover the smear.
  2.  Rinse with distilled water.
  3. Decolorize by flooding with 3% acid-alcohol.
  4. Let the slide sit for 2-3 minutes.
  5. Heat the slide with a flame to allow stain penetration.
  6. Air dry the slide.
  7. Apply methylene blue as a counterstain.

 

The correct sequence is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) i, v, ii, iii, iv, vii, vi

 

The Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining process is designed to identify acid-fast bacteria, particularly Mycobacterium species, by distinguishing acid-fast from non-acid-fast bacteria. Each step is essential for preparing the sample, applying the stain, decolorizing, and counterstaining, so the acid-fast organisms are clearly visible under a microscope. The correct steps in sequence are as follows:

 

  1. Apply Carbol Fuchsin (Step i): This primary stain binds to acid-fast bacteria.
  2. Heat the Slide (Step v): Gentle heating helps the stain penetrate the waxy cell walls of acid-fast bacteria.
  3. Rinse with Distilled Water (Step ii): Washing removes excess carbol fuchsin.
  4. Decolorize with Acid-Alcohol (Step iii): Acid-alcohol removes the stain from non-acid-fast bacteria, while acid-fast bacteria retain it.
  5. Let Stand for 2-3 Minutes (Step iv): Allowing time ensures thorough decolorization.
  6. Apply Methylene Blue (Step vii): This counterstain provides contrast by staining non-acid-fast bacteria.
  7. Air Dry the Slide (Step vi): The slide is allowed to dry before examination under a microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective Ziehl-Neelsen staining, the sequence involves applying carbol fuchsin with heat, followed by decolorization with acid-alcohol, counterstaining with methylene blue, and drying.

questions.text: Which inhaled anesthetic agent is preferred for pediatric induction of anesthesia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhaled anesthetic agent for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients. This is primarily due to its pleasant, sweet smell, which makes it more tolerable for children to inhale. Additionally, Sevoflurane has a rapid onset of action, meaning it works quickly to induce anesthesia. This quick induction is critical in pediatric patients who often do not have an intravenous (IV) line placed before induction. The ability to induce anesthesia effectively and without distress is a significant advantage in this age group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is not preferred for pediatric induction because it has a pungent odor, which can be irritating and unpleasant for children. Moreover, it can cause airway irritation, which is undesirable during induction.

 

Option C. Isoflurane: While Isoflurane is effective as an anesthetic, it also has a pungent smell and slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane, making it less ideal for pediatric use.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane was previously used for pediatric induction, but it has largely fallen out of favor due to its potential for causing liver toxicity and its slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:


Sevoflurane is the anesthetic agent of choice for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its sweet smell and rapid onset of action.

questions.text: As filtrate flows through PCT, the concentration of all of the following decreases except: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

Normally in the PCT, Glucose & Amino Acid maximally approx. 100% reabsorbed; Bicarbonate approx.-80-85% and about 60-70 per cent of the filtered load of sodium and water and a slightly lower percentage of filtered chloride are reabsorbed by the proximal tubule before the filtrate reaches the loops of Henle. Hence, the concentration of chloride relatively increases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acid: The concentration of amino acids decreases significantly as they are almost entirely reabsorbed in the PCT.

 

Option B. Glucose: Glucose concentration also decreases drastically due to nearly complete reabsorption in the PCT.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: A large percentage of bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the PCT, leading to a decrease in its concentration in the filtrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), the concentration of chloride increases relative to other substances, which are more extensively reabsorbed. This includes glucose and amino acids, which are almost completely reabsorbed, and bicarbonate, which is substantially reabsorbed.

questions.text: A lesion involving the structure indicated by the arrow in the given image would most likely result in which of the following clinical findings? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Contralateral hemiplegia

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the pyramid containing the pyramidal tracts. A lesion here leads to contralateral hemiplegia.

 

This is because the fibers of these tracts decussate (cross over) in the medulla oblongata. Thus, an injury to the pyramidal tract on one side of the brain or upper spinal cord will affect motor function on the opposite side of the body.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ataxia: Ataxia refers to uncoordinated movement and is typically related to damage to the cerebellum or sensory pathways, not the pyramidal tracts. The cerebellum plays a crucial role in fine-tuning motor movements and ensuring coordination. So, an injury to the pyramidal tracts does not typically result in ataxia.

 

Option C. Tinnitus: Tinnitus is the perception of noise or ringing in the ears. It's a symptom of an underlying condition, such as age-related hearing loss, ear injury, or a circulatory system disorder. Injury to the pyramidal tracts would not lead to tinnitus, as they are primarily motor tracts and not involved in auditory processing or function.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral facial palsy: Facial palsy refers to weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. It is most commonly associated with damage to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). While the pyramidal tracts do play a role in voluntary facial movements, a direct injury to these tracts would not typically lead to ipsilateral facial palsy. Furthermore, facial movements are controlled by both sides of the brain, so an isolated pyramidal tract lesion might not manifest as overt facial weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pyramids in the medulla oblongata, containing the pyramidal tracts, are crucial for voluntary motor control. A lesion here can lead to contralateral hemiplegia due to the crossing over of these tracts within the medulla. This understanding is essential for diagnosing and understanding the implications of brainstem injuries, especially in the context of stroke or other neurological disorders.

questions.text: In the infectious disease ward, you notice a multi-drug therapy packet placed neatly on a patient's bedside table. Based on the drug composition, which of the following diseases do you think the packet is intended to treat? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Leprosy

 

The given image shows the adult blister packet used in the treatment of leprosy.

 

 

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB: TB treatment involves a different combination of drugs, typically including isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.

 

Option C. Vaginal discharge: Treatment for vaginal discharge depends on the specific cause, such as bacterial, fungal, or protozoal infection, and usually involves single-agent therapy.

 

Option D. Gonorrhea: Gonorrhea treatment generally involves antibiotics like ceftriaxone and azithromycin, not a multi-drug blister packet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multi-drug therapy packets containing drugs like rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone are specifically intended for the treatment of leprosy.

questions.text: You're rotating in the infection control unit of a tertiary care hospital in Chennai. As part of your duties, you have been assigned to educate the staff about the importance of precautionary measures and isolation techniques for various conditions. While discussing droplet precautions, one of the staff inquired about the diseases for which such precautions are necessary. Which of the following conditions does NOT typically require precautionary measures and isolation due to droplet infection? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Localized varicella zoster

 

  • Droplet precautions and isolation are unnecessary for localized varicella-zoster, as this virus is exclusively transmitted through direct contact.
  • When varicella-zoster remains confined to a patient with a fully functioning immune system and can be effectively contained or covered, there is no need for droplet precautions.
  • However, if varicella becomes disseminated in any patient, it necessitates both airborne and contact precautions.
  • On the other hand, diseases like diphtheria, pertussis, and mycoplasma are transmitted via droplets and, therefore, demand droplet precautions and isolation measures.
  • These precautions include the use of masks, gowns, gloves, and protective eye gear when delivering direct patient care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pertussis: Requires droplet precautions due to transmission via respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Diphtheria: Requires droplet precautions as it is spread through respiratory droplets.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma pneumonia: Requires droplet precautions due to transmission via respiratory droplets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Localized varicella zoster does not require droplet precautions as it is transmitted through direct contact, while conditions like pertussis, diphtheria, and mycoplasma pneumonia require droplet precautions due to their transmission via respiratory droplets.

questions.text: Severe intractable pain in the leg due to sciatica in a patient with carcinoma rectum is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior infiltration in females

 

The most appropriate and specific answer is that sciatica in patients with rectal carcinoma occurs due to anterior infiltration in females.

 

Sciatica associated with rectal carcinoma is a result of perineural invasion of the inferior hypogastric plexus, which gives rise to the sciatic nerve. The location of this plexus differs between males and females:

 

  • In females, the inferior hypogastric plexus lies anterolateral to the rectum.
  • In males, the plexus is located lateral to the rectum.

 

Thus, in females, infiltration occurs anteriorly, making anterior infiltration in females the most specific answer for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior infiltration in males: The inferior hypogastric plexus lies lateral, not anterior, to the rectum in males.

 

Option C. Lateral infiltration: While the hypogastric plexus is lateral in males, lateral infiltration does not explain sciatica due to rectal carcinoma in females.

 

Option D. Posterior infiltration: The hypogastric plexus is not located posteriorly in relation to the rectum in either males or females, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sciatica in rectal carcinoma patients, particularly in females, is often due to anterior infiltration of the inferior hypogastric plexus, which supplies the sciatic nerve. Understanding the anatomical differences in the positioning of the plexus between males and females is crucial in diagnosing the cause of sciatic pain in these patients.

questions.text: RNAi acts through? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Knock down

 

Explanation:

 

Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knock out: This involves removing or taking a gene out, resulting in a complete loss of gene function.

 

Option C. Knock in: This involves inserting a gene into a specific location within the genome.

 

Option D. Knock up: This term is not used in the context of gene manipulation.

 

Educational Objective:


RNA interference (RNAi) acts through gene knock down by suppressing the function of a gene via degradation or inhibition of its target mRNA, preventing protein formation.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 346-348

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anovulation

 

Explanation:

 

Anovulation is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia. Menorrhagia refers to heavy menstrual bleeding that occurs in a regular cycle. In adolescents, anovulation, which is the failure of the ovary to release an oocyte during a menstrual cycle, frequently leads to heavy or prolonged bleeding due to the lack of a normal hormonal cycle that regulates the endometrial lining. Without the usual cyclical hormonal fluctuations, the endometrial lining may become excessively thick, leading to heavy bleeding when it sheds. This condition is typical in puberty due to the body's ongoing adjustment to hormonal regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, which can cause painful menstruation and potentially contribute to menorrhagia. However, it is less common than anovulation as the primary cause of menorrhagia in adolescents.

 

Option C. Malignancy: Malignancy is a rare cause of menorrhagia in puberty. While malignancy can lead to abnormal bleeding, it is not the most common cause in this age group.

 

Option D. Bleeding disorder: Bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease or hemophilia can cause menorrhagia but are less common compared to anovulation in adolescents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anovulation is the most common cause of menorrhagia in puberty.

choices.text: 2 and 4 are correct
1, 3 and 5 are correct
1, 4 and 5 are correct
2, 4 and 5 are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarization, Repolarization, and hyperpolarization in a skeletal muscle action potential?(INICET May 2020)

 

  1. Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
  2. Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through ligand-gated channels
  3. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a voltage-gated channel
  4. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a ligand-gated channel
  5. Hyperpolarization due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 5 are correct

 

Action potential in skeletal muscle:

 

During the onset of depolarization, voltage gated sodium channels open and there is slow influx of Na+. When depolarization reaches 7 to 10 mV, the voltage gated Na+ channels start opening at a faster rate. It is called Na+ channel activation. When the firing level is reached, the influx of Na+ is very great and it leads to overshoot.

 

But the Na+ transport is short lived. It is because of rapid inactivation of Na+ channels. Thus, the Na+ channels open and close quickly. At the same time, the K+ channels start opening. This leads to efflux of K+ out of the cell, causing repolarization.

 

Unlike the Na+ channels, the K+ channels remain open for longer duration. These channels remain opened for few more milliseconds after completion of repolarization. It causes efflux of a greater number of K+ producing more negativity inside. It is the cause for hyperpolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 and 4 are correct: Incorrect. Depolarization in skeletal muscle is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels. Repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Option C. 1, 4 and 5 are correct: Incorrect. Repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Option D. 2, 4 and 5 are correct: Incorrect. Depolarization in skeletal muscle is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels, and repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In skeletal muscle action potential, depolarization occurs due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, repolarization occurs due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, and hyperpolarization is caused by the prolonged efflux of K+.

questions.text: All of the following are true about oculomotor nerve palsy except:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral and upward gaze

 

Lateral and upward gaze is a sign of trochlear nerve palsy, not of oculomotor palsy. Oculomotor nerve palsy leads to lateral and downward gaze.

 

Signs of oculomotor nerve palsy

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out") due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ptosis Occurs due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

 

Option B. Mid-dilated pupil: Results from paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle, leading to unopposed dilation by the sympathetic innervation.

 

Option C. Loss of light reflex: Occurs because the parasympathetic fibers controlling pupillary constriction are affected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Oculomotor nerve palsy typically causes an "down and out" gaze due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, not a "lateral and upward" gaze, which would instead suggest trochlear nerve involvement.

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B)  5’→ 3’ Exonuclease

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg’s enzyme) was isolated from Escherichia coli. It is a repair enzyme. It has both 3’ to 5’ and 5’ to 3’ exonuclease activities. When 5’ to 3’ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

The Klenow fragment retains the polymerization (5' → 3' DNA polymerase) and proofreading (3' → 5' exonuclease) activities but lacks the 5' → 3' exonuclease activity. Because of these retained activities, the Klenow fragment is widely used in recombinant DNA technology for applications that require DNA synthesis and proofreading without the degradation of the DNA template.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3' → 5' Exonuclease: The Klenow fragment retains this activity, which allows it to proofread and correct errors during DNA synthesis.

 

Option C. 5' → 3' DNA polymerase: The Klenow fragment retains this activity, which is essential for synthesizing new DNA strands.

 

Option D. 3' → 5' DNA polymerase: This activity is not applicable in the context of DNA polymerase I and the Klenow fragment, as DNA polymerase functions in the 5' → 3' direction for synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I retains the 5' → 3' DNA polymerase and 3' → 5' exonuclease (proofreading) activities but lacks the 5' → 3' exonuclease activity, making it useful for specific applications in recombinant DNA technology.

questions.text:
Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Non-scarring alopecia is characterized by hair loss without destruction of the hair follicle, allowing for the potential regrowth of hair. The options provided include three conditions that typically result in non-scarring alopecia:

 

1. Alopecia areata: An autoimmune disorder that causes patchy hair loss on the scalp and other parts of the body. This condition is non-scarring, as the hair follicles are not destroyed and hair can regrow if the underlying autoimmune process is controlled or subsides.

 

2. Telogen effluvium: A condition characterized by widespread thinning of the hair, often triggered by a significant stress event, illness, or hormonal change. It results from a large number of hair follicles entering the resting phase (telogen) simultaneously. Recovery is possible once the triggering event is resolved, and the follicles remain intact.

 

3. Androgenic alopecia: Commonly known as male or female pattern baldness, this is a genetic condition influenced by androgens (hormones). It involves hair thinning in a characteristic pattern and is non-scarring, as the hair follicles gradually produce thinner, shorter hairs but are not completely destroyed.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a form of scarring alopecia. It involves a progressive, symmetrical band of hair loss at the front of the scalp along with loss of eyebrows. The scarring means that the hair follicles are permanently destroyed, preventing the regrowth of hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information

questions.text:
A child presents with acute exacerbation of asthma. Which of the following would you do? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Chest X-ray
  2. Oxygen administration
  3. Salbutamol nebulization three times in 60 minutes
  4. Administration of oral corticosteroids
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3 ,4

 

A child coming with acute exacerbation of asthma will be administered oxygen, salbutamol nebulization three times in 60 minutes, and oral corticosteroids.

 

Exacerbation of asthma involves an increase in symptoms such as cough, wheezing, and/or breathlessness. If the child has cyanosis, silent chest, poor respiratory effort, altered sensorium, and oxygen saturation of <90%, the exacerbation is considered life-threatening.

 

Based on severity, acute asthma is classified as mild, moderate, and severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3, 4: While salbutamol nebulization and oral corticosteroids are important in managing an asthma exacerbation, omitting oxygen therapy (especially in cases of hypoxia) is incorrect.

 

Option B. 1, 4:  A chest X-ray is not routinely indicated in acute asthma exacerbations unless there is suspicion of another underlying condition (e.g., pneumonia, pneumothorax). Oxygen therapy and salbutamol nebulization are key for immediate management.

 

Option C. 1, 3, 4:  Similar to option B, a chest X-ray is not immediately necessary unless there is concern for an alternative diagnosis or complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute exacerbation of asthma, management includes oxygen therapy, salbutamol nebulization, and oral corticosteroids. A chest X-ray is only indicated if complications or other diagnoses are suspected.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are typically associated with glomerular hematuria? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Brown urine
  2. Dysuria absent
  3. Crystals in urine
  4. Edema is rare
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B

 

Glomerular hematuria has specific characteristics that help differentiate it from non-glomerular causes:

 

A. Brown urine: Brown/cola-colored urine is typical of glomerular hematuria due to the presence of RBCs.

 

B. Dysuria absent: Absence of dysuria is characteristic, as there is no urinary tract inflammation or infection.

 

These findings together strongly suggest glomerular origin of hematuria.

 

Other Options:

 

C. Crystals in urine: Incorrect. Crystalluria is not a feature of glomerular hematuria. Instead, findings like dysmorphic RBCs, acanthocytes, or RBC casts are characteristic.

 

D. Edema is rare: Incorrect. Edema is common in glomerular diseases, whether nephritic or nephrotic, due to:

 

  • Loss of albumin leading to decreased oncotic pressure
  • Activation of the renin-angiotensin system
  • Underlying inflammatory processes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular hematuria includes brown/cola-colored urine and absence of dysuria, while presence of edema and absence of urinary crystals are other important characteristics.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain, photophobia and redness of the right eye since 2 days. He gave a history of injury by a leaf, to the same eye, 5 days back. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fungal corneal ulcer

 

The given clinical situation suggests that it is a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter or injury by animal tail.

 

A very characteristic feature of fungal corneal ulcer is that the Signs are much more than Symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior uveitis: This involves inflammation of the middle layer of the eye, which can cause pain and redness but does not involve the specific corneal changes seen in fungal ulcers.

 

Option B. Conjunctivitis: An inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid, typically causing redness and discharge, not the specific features of a corneal ulcer.

 

Option D. Corneal laceration: While also a result of trauma, lacerations would generally present immediately post-injury with sharp, distinct cuts, rather than developing signs of infection such as those described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fungal corneal ulcer should be considered when a patient presents with eye symptoms following trauma involving vegetative or organic material. Key diagnostic features include a greyish-white ulcer with feathery margins, potentially accompanied by a hypopyon, and absence of corneal vascularization.

questions.text: Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017, a patient has the right to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment. What is this provision known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Advance directive

 

The Mental Health Care Act 2017 introduced a provision allowing individuals to specify in advance the manner in which they would like to be cared for and treated in the event they develop a mental illness in the future. This provision is called an "Advance Directive." The advance directive allows a person to specify how they want to be treated, what treatments they don't want, and to nominate a person to be their representative.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions. Individuals can also appoint “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in taking decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decision.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. A histology image is shown below. What can be the diagnosis for this patient?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwannoma

 

The given clinical scenario and histology image showing Verocay bodies are suggestive of Schwannoma /Acoustic neuroma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibroma is a benign tumor that develops along nerve cells. Histology image shows wreath like multinucleated giant cells.

 

 

Option B. Leiomyoma on histology shows well-differentiated, regular, spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with hyalinization.

 

 

Option D. Rhabdomyoma on microscopy shows enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. Post-processing, glycogen content gets reduced and look like thin strands.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannoma is a benign tumor often associated with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, diagnosed via characteristic histological patterns and confirmed with MRI. It requires careful management, sometimes involving advanced surgical techniques such as Gamma Knife surgery.

questions.text: A patient with ulcerative colitis is experiencing three episodes of bleeding in stools per day but is otherwise stable. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-Aminosalicylic acid.

 

5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis, especially in a stable patient who is experiencing active symptoms like bleeding. It works as an anti-inflammatory agent in the colon and is effective in inducing and maintaining remission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5-Fluorouracil: This is a chemotherapeutic agent and is not used for treating ulcerative colitis. It's primarily used in cancer treatment.

 

Option C. Budesonide: While budesonide, a corticosteroid, is used in ulcerative colitis, it's generally reserved for more severe cases or when 5-ASA is ineffective. In a stable patient, it may not be the first choice.

 

Option D. 6-Mercaptopurine: This is an immunosuppressant used in ulcerative colitis primarily for maintenance therapy or in patients who haven't responded to other treatments, not typically as a first-line treatment in a stable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis and is effective in reducing inflammation and maintaining remission in stable patients experiencing active symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt. He underwent myringoplasty for the safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) 6 months back. What is your diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perilymphatic fistula

 

  • The clinical scenario with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt and history of myringoplasty done for CSOM suggest that the diagnosis is perilymphatic fistula.
  • A peri-lymphatic fistula is an abnormal communication between the inner ear and the middle ear that can allow perilymph to leak from the cochlea or vestibule, most commonly through the round or oval window.
  • Precipitating causes include surgery, blunt trauma, penetrating trauma, barotrauma, infection, cholesteatoma, or sudden changes in CSF pressure as can occur with straining, sneezing, or Valsalva’s maneuver. Congenital ear abnormalities may predispose to perilymph leaks. Spontaneous perilymph fistulae are rare.
  • The clinical picture of perilymph fistulae is variable, with symptoms ranging from mild to incapacitating. Vertigo, or more often unsteadiness, is the most common symptom. Hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness may be present. A thorough history inquiring about activities such as trauma, scuba diving, flying, and straining is critical in the diagnosis of this disorder as the symptoms are vague and coincident with other vestibular disorders. Fistula test is positive.

 

Investigations

 

  • HRCT temporal bone has high sensitivity in detecting peri lymphatic fistula.
  • A combination of CT and MRI diagnose almost 100% of cases.
  • Other tests include audiometry and electrocochleography.

 

Management of a peri-lymphatic fistula is either by conservative or surgical methods. Conservative therapy includes avoiding anything that can increase inner ear or intracranial pressure and the use of intratympanic steroids in acute decompensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labyrinthitis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating and pallor and sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option C. Paget's disease of bone usually presents with hearing loss as a prominent feature, when the skull is involved. It is not associated with a history of surgery, trauma or vestibulocochlear symptoms.

 

Option D. Vestibular Schwannoma, also called as acoustic neuroma is a tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular, but rarely from the cochlear division of vestibulocochlear nerve within the internal auditory canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymphatic fistula should be suspected in patients presenting with vestibular symptoms following ear surgery, particularly when associated with activities that change intracranial or middle ear pressure. Diagnosis is largely based on clinical history, symptomatology, and specific imaging tests.

choices.text: Mono-unsaturated fatty acids
Poly-unsaturated fatty acids

questions.text: Which require maximum energy for assimilation? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proteins

 

Option A. Proteins:

  • Proteins are complex macromolecules consisting of amino acids.
  • They require a significant amount of energy for assimilation because the body needs to break them down into individual amino acids, which are then used for various metabolic processes, including energy production.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Carbohydrates:

  • Carbohydrates are a primary source of energy for the body.
  • They are relatively easy to assimilate as they are broken down into glucose, which can be readily used for energy.

 

Option C. Mono-unsaturated fatty acids:

  • Mono-unsaturated fatty acids are a type of dietary fat found in foods like olive oil and avocados.
  • They require less energy for assimilation compared to proteins because they can be broken down relatively easily and used for energy or stored as fat.

 

Option D. Poly-unsaturated fatty acids:

  • Poly-unsaturated fatty acids, such as omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, are essential fats found in certain foods.
  • Similar to mono-unsaturated fatty acids, they require less energy for assimilation compared to proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proteins require the maximum energy for assimilation among the options listed, as they need to be broken down into individual amino acids for various metabolic processes, including energy production.

choices.text: Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule

questions.text: Identify the correct match out of the following diuretics and the respective site of action: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule

 

Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors: These diuretics inhibit the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which is located predominantly in the proximal convoluted tubule. This inhibition reduces the reabsorption of bicarbonate, sodium, and water in this segment, making "Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule" the correct match.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osmotic diuretics: These have a diffuse mechanism of action throughout the nephron, primarily affecting water-permeable regions such as the proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle. The statement "Osmotic diuretics → Collecting duct" is incorrect as the major sites of action are the proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb, not just the collecting duct.

 

Option C. Thiazides: Thiazide diuretics act on the distal convoluted tubule by inhibiting the sodium-chloride transporter. They do not primarily act on the Loop of Henle, making "Thiazides → Loop of Henle" incorrect.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonists: These drugs act on the collecting ducts, particularly affecting the principal cells where aldosterone promotes sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion. Therefore, the statement "Aldosterone antagonists → Distal Convoluted tubule" is incorrect as their primary site of action is the collecting duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diuretics with their site of action:

 

  • Osmotic diuretics → Proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle
  • Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule
  • Thiazides → Distal convoluted tubule
  • Aldosterone antagonists → Collecting duct

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the condition seen in the image? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pterygium

 

  • The given image shows Pterygium which is a triangular/wing shaped encroachment of conjunctiva on the cornea.

 

PTERYGIUM:

 

  • A pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of degenerative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea.
  • Typically develops in patients who have been living in sunny countries and may represent a response to UV exposure and chronic surface dryness.
  • Familial.
  • Histologically similar to a pinguecula: shows elastotic degenerative changes in vascularized subepithelial stromal collagen.
  • Encroaches onto the cornea, invading the Bowman layer.
  • Clinical features 
    • Mostly asymptomatic.
    • Irritation and grittiness are caused by a dellen – localized drying effect.
    • Lesions may interfere with vision by obscuring the visual axis or inducing astigmatism.
    • Cosmesis may be a significant problem.
    • Extensive lesions (if recurrent) may have subconjunctival fibrosis extending to the fornices causing restricted ocular excursion.
    • Made up of three parts: a ‘cap’ (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head and a body.
    • Linear epithelial iron deposition (Stocker line): seen in the corneal epithelium anterior to the head of the pterygium.
    • Fuchs islets are small discrete whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells often present at the advancing edge.
    • Aggressive growth or an atypical appearance should prompt excision biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: Unlike pterygium, a pinguecula does not grow across the cornea but remains confined to the conjunctiva. It appears as a yellowish, slightly raised lesion on the conjunctiva near the cornea, usually on the nasal side.

 

Option C. Chemical Burn: This would typically present with more diffuse redness, possible corneal haze, and severe discomfort. The eye would look more acutely inflamed and could show signs of limbal ischemia or whitening.

 

Option D. Thermal Burn: Similar to chemical burns, a thermal burn would involve more diffuse damage and typically present signs of acute injury, such as eyelid burns, charred lashes, or more extensive tissue damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium is identifiable by its characteristic growth from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, often due to prolonged UV exposure, appearing as a wing-shaped film on the eye.

questions.text: Hooch tragedy is related to which of the following alcohols?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methyl alcohol

 

Option A. Methyl alcohol (Correct Answer): Hooch tragedies are typically associated with the consumption of illicit liquor that contains methanol. Methanol is toxic to the human body and can lead to serious health issues, including organ damage and even death, when consumed in significant amounts.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ethyl alcohol: Ethyl alcohol, also known as ethanol, is the type of alcohol commonly found in alcoholic beverages that are legally produced and regulated. It is not typically associated with hooch tragedies.
