Option C. Ethylene glycol: Ethylene glycol is not related to hooch tragedies. It is a chemical compound used in products such as antifreeze and is highly toxic when ingested.

 

Option D. Hypoglycin: Hypoglycin is a naturally occurring toxin found in certain plants, such as the ackee fruit, and is not directly related to hooch tragedies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Country liquor can be categorised as spurious liquor or hooch when the amount of methane added could turn fatal. There are number of death cases reported every year due to consumption of such alcohol.

 

The metabolism of methyl alcohol is shown in figure below:

 

 

The formaldehyde and formic acid formed as products during the metabolism can cause severe metabolic acidosis, blindness and neurologic damage.

 

The treatment involves administration of ethanol or Fomepizole which act as competitive inhibitors of enzyme ADH and prevent the formation of these two products.

questions.text: A patient who is suffering from a pressure sore on examination is found to have partially broken skin with a shallow ulcer. What is the grade of the sore? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

Pressure sore grading:

 

  • Grade 1: Non-blanching erythema with intact skin
  • Grade 2: Partial thickness skin loss involving epidermis/dermis, shallow ulcer
  • Grade 3: Full thickness skin loss with visible subcutaneous fat
  • Grade 4: Full thickness tissue loss with exposed bone/muscle/tendon In this case,  partial skin loss with shallow ulcer indicates Grade 2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade 1:

 

  • Only shows non-blanching erythema
  • Skin remains intact
  • No ulceration present

 

Option C. Grade 3:

 

  • Shows full-thickness skin loss
  • Subcutaneous fat visible
  • Deeper than described in question

 

Option D. Grade 4:

 

  • Represents full thickness tissue loss
  • Exposes deeper structures (bone/muscle/tendon)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade 2 pressure sore is characterized by partial thickness skin loss with shallow ulceration, without exposure of deeper tissues.

 

Stages:

 

  1. Non blanching erythema with intact skin
  2. Partial thickness skin loss (some skin intact)
  3. Full thickness loss (subcut, Fat seen)
  4. Subcut, Loss (deep fascia/muscles/bones tendons seen)

 

 

Management:

 

  • Avoid continuous supine position → frequent change in position 
  • Use of air mattress/water bed
  • Cover the pressure sore: fascia lata flap/ negative pressure wound therapy (VAC dressing)

choices.text: Anti CTLA 4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers
Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases antigen toxicity
PD1/ PDL1 activation leading to tumor suppression
Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding immune surveillance? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti CTLA 4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers

 

CTLA4 is a negative regulator of T-cell responses. recognition of tumor cells may lead to engagement of the T-cell inhibitory receptor, CTLA4, or activation of regulatory T cells that suppress immune responses. Antibodies that block the interaction of CTLA-4 with its ligands B7. 1 and B7. 2 can enhance immune responses, including anti-tumor immunity.

 

Ipilimumab, a fully humanized IgG1 monoclonal Anti CTLA-4 antibody, has shown a significant improvement in survival of advanced-stage melanoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases antigen toxicity: This statement is incorrect because mutations in tumor suppressor genes (e.g., TP53) lead to the loss of cell cycle control and contribute to tumorigenesis, not decreased antigen toxicity.

 

Option C. PD1/PDL1 activation leading to tumor suppression: The PD-1/PD-L1 pathway is another immune checkpoint that, when activated, suppresses the immune response. In cancer, tumors often upregulate PD-L1 to evade immune destruction, so this pathway is involved in immune evasion, not suppression of tumors.

 

Option D. Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance: CD28 is a co-stimulatory molecule that, when bound to B7 on APCs, promotes T-cell activation rather than tolerance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-CTLA-4 antibodies like Ipilimumab are a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers, enhancing the anti-tumor immune response by blocking inhibitory signals to T cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 574

choices.text: Inhibition of calcineurin
AMP kinase stimulation
IMP dehydrogenase inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin
 

  • Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant drug that acts by inhibiting Calcineurin.
  • Calcineurin is a calcium/calmodulin-dependent phosphatase required for the induction of T cell lymphokine production and proliferation.
  • Cyclosporine inhibits calcineurin activity by forming a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein present in target cells, to form a cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex. This drug-receptor complex specifically and competitively binds to and inhibits calcineurin.
  • This, in turn, inhibits the translocation of a family of transcription factors (NF-AT), leading to reduced transcriptional activation of cytokine genes for interleukin (IL)-2 and other factors.
  • Ultimately, the proliferation of T lymphocytes is reduced, resulting in immunomodulation.
  • Indications: It is the most effective drug for the prevention of Graft rejection reaction. It is also used as a second line drug in autoimmune disease like severe Rheumatoid arthritis, uveitis, inflammatory bowel disease and dermatomyositis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AMP kinase is stimulated by metformin used in treating T2DM
 

Option C. IMP dehydrogenase is inhibited by mycophenolate mofetil, also used in the prophylaxis of transplant rejection.

 

Option D. Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase is inhibited by leflunomide, a pyrimidine synthesis inhibitor indicated for the management of rheumatoid arthritis in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclosporine exerts its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting calcineurin, thereby preventing the activation of T cells and reducing the production of cytokines such as IL-2. This mechanism is crucial for its role in preventing graft rejection and managing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of heavy metal toxicity. Laboratory investigations confirm the presence of heavy metal ions in the patient's bloodstream. The medical team is considering chelation therapy to bind and facilitate the excretion of the toxic metals. Which of the following agents is NOT typically used for the treatment of heavy metal toxicity? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oximes

 

The agents listed are all chelating agents except for oximes, which are not typically used for heavy metal toxicity.

 

Oximes, such as pralidoxime, are used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase that has been inactivated by organophosphate poisoning, not heavy metal toxicity. They do not have a chelating effect on heavy metals and are therefore not used in the treatment of heavy metal toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BAL (British Anti-Lewisite): BAL is a chelating agent used to treat arsenic, gold, and mercury poisoning. It works by binding to the heavy metal ions, forming a complex that can be excreted from the body.

 

Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): EDTA is another chelating agent that binds to lead and other heavy metals. It is used in cases of lead poisoning and can also chelate other metals such as zinc, cadmium, and manganese.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is used in the treatment of copper toxicity, such as Wilson's disease, and can also chelate mercury and lead. It binds to the metals and helps remove them from the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oximes are not used for heavy metal chelation and are specifically used to treat organophosphate poisoning by reactivating acetylcholinesterase. Chelating agents like BAL, EDTA, and penicillamine are typically used for heavy metal toxicity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with NYHA Class III heart failure presents with shortness of breath, peripheral edema, and laboratory findings showing a potassium level of 5.5 mEq/L and a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. Which of the following drugs would NOT be contraindicated in this scenario? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Furosemide

 

In this patient with heart failure and hyperkalemia (potassium of 5.5 mEq/L), certain medications that can increase potassium levels are contraindicated. Furosemide, a loop diuretic, is preferred in such a scenario because it helps in potassium excretion, thereby lowering potassium levels. Therefore, furosemide is not contraindicated in this patient and may be beneficial in reducing the edema and hyperkalemia associated with heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Although digoxin does not directly affect potassium levels, it can become toxic in the presence of electrolyte imbalances, including hyperkalemia. Therefore, close monitoring is required, and digoxin should be used cautiously.

 

Option B. Spironolactone: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic and is typically avoided in patients with elevated potassium levels, as it can worsen hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Enalapril: An ACE inhibitor, enalapril can increase potassium levels by reducing aldosterone secretion, further contributing to hyperkalemia. Thus, it should be avoided in patients with hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In heart failure patients with hyperkalemia, furosemide is a safe choice as it promotes potassium excretion. Drugs that increase potassium levels, such as spironolactone and ACE inhibitors, should be avoided.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aberrant right subclavian artery

 

The CT scan image provided shows an anatomical variant where there is an extra vessel coursing behind the esophagus towards the right side. Normally, there are three major arch arteries visible at this level. However, in this image, an additional vessel is seen, which is characteristic of an aberrant right subclavian artery.

 

The aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variation where the right subclavian artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and passes posterior to the esophagus. This can lead to a condition known as dysphagia lusoria, where the esophagus is compressed by the artery, causing difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right sided aortic arch: This condition involves the aortic arch itself being positioned on the right side, which is not indicated by the presence of an extra vessel behind the esophagus in this image.

 

Option C. Tracheal diverticulum: A tracheal diverticulum would appear as an air-filled outpouching from the trachea. The image does not show any such outpouching or abnormality of the trachea.

 

Option D. Esophageal duplication: This is a rare congenital condition where a duplicated segment of the esophagus is present. The image does not show an additional lumen or any signs indicative of esophageal duplication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variant where the artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and courses posterior to the esophagus, often leading to dysphagia lusoria due to esophageal compression.

choices.text: Echocardiography for cardiac disease
Urine analysis for bacteriuria
Blood sugar levels for GDM
VDRL for syphilis

questions.text: The following cost-effective investigations are routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echocardiography for cardiac disease

 

Explanation:

 

Echocardiography for cardiac disease is not part of routine antenatal screening. While it is important for detecting cardiac conditions, echocardiography is typically performed only if there is a known or suspected cardiac disease. Routine screening for all antenatal mothers does not include echocardiography due to its cost and the specific indications required for its use.

 

Routine antenatal screening is designed to identify common conditions that may affect the health of the mother and baby.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Urine analysis for bacteriuriaUrine analysis for bacteriuria: This test is routinely performed to detect asymptomatic bacteriuria, which, if left untreated, can lead to urinary tract infections and increase the risk of preterm labor.

 

Option C. Blood sugar levels for GDM Blood sugar levels for GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus): Screening for GDM is essential to identify women who develop diabetes during pregnancy, which can affect both maternal and fetal health.

 

Option D. VDRL for syphilis: The VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test is a screening tool for syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection that can have serious consequences for both the mother and the baby if left untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Routine antenatal screening does not include echocardiography for cardiac disease unless there is a known or suspected condition.

 

Ref: Page no 110, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A servant was sexually assaulted by her boss. There was presence of white stains on the clothes of the victim. Barberio's test was performed on the stains. Which of the following is detected by this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spermine

 

  • Barberio’s test detects the presence of spermine (prostatic component of semen).
  • In this test the alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to dried seminal stain which produces the yellow needle shaped crystals are of spermine picrate.

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Acid phosphatase: It is detected in acid phosphatase test

 

Option C) Choline: It is detected in Florence test

 

Option D) Fructose: Produced by Seminal vesicles, but not commonly detected

 

Educational Objective

 

Tests for seminal stains

 

1) Presumptive test for seminal stains:

 

  • Fluorescence under UV light
  • Microchemical tests: ﻿﻿Florence test and ﻿Barberio's test   

 

2) Confirmatory Tests for Semen

 

  • Detection of complete sperm under the microscope (Best test)﻿﻿
  • Acid phosphatase test (second best test): It is produced by prostate gland. Acid phosphatase enzyme in semen is much higher concentration than other body fluids
  • ﻿﻿Creatine phosphokinase test: It is a component of Spermatozoa.
  • Prostate specific antigen

questions.text: Pterygium can lead to which of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Astigmatism

 

Explanation: 


Pterygium can lead to astigmatism because the fibrous growth on the cornea tends to flatten the cornea in the horizontal meridian. This creates an irregular corneal surface, specifically causing with-the-rule astigmatism. The pterygium grows along the horizontal axis, making it flatter, which results in the vertical axis becoming comparatively steeper, leading to astigmatism. This condition may cause visual disturbance, especially if it grows across the pupil.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Eye Pain: This is incorrect. Pterygium is typically painless. Patients may experience foreign body sensation, but actual pain is not a characteristic feature.

 

Option C. Macular edema: This is incorrect. Pterygium is a surface growth that affects the anterior segment of the eye and does not cause macular edema, which is a condition affecting the posterior segment.

 

Option D. Purulent Discharge: This is incorrect. Pterygium is a non-inflammatory condition and does not cause purulent discharge. While there might be mild irritation and tearing, purulent discharge is not associated with pterygium.

 

Educational Objective:


Pterygium can cause with-the-rule astigmatism by flattening the cornea in the horizontal meridian.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of NAME syndrome? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ebstein's anomaly

 

NAME syndrome is now recognized as part of the Carney complex, which falls under Multiple Endocrine Other Organ Neoplasia (MEON). The NAME acronym stands for:

 

  • N: Nevi (blue nevi – skin manifestation)
  • A: Atrial myxoma
  • M: Myxoid neurofibroma
  • E: Ephelides (freckles)

 

Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


NAME syndrome (now part of Carney complex) consists of Nevi (blue), Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibroma, and Ephelides (freckles). Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

questions.text: What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1:1000 I.M. - 0.5 ml

 

Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs is associated with the increased risk of fractures? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rosiglitazone

 

Rosiglitazone, a drug belonging to the class of thiazolidinediones, has been associated with an increased risk of bone fractures. The mechanism behind this is not fully understood, but it is thought that thiazolidinediones might interfere with bone metabolism (PPARγ agonist), leading to decreased bone mineral density which can increase the risk of fractures, especially in postmenopausal women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liraglutide: It is a GLP-1 receptor agonist used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. There is no strong evidence linking liraglutide to an increased risk of fractures.

 

Option C. Voglibose: It is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor which delays the absorption of carbohydrates from the intestines. It has not been primarily associated with an increased risk of fractures.

 

Option D. Canagliflozin: It is one of the SGLT2 inhibitors that works by removing glucose through the urine. While there have been some discussions about bone density changes with SGLT2 inhibitors, canagliflozin specifically has had mixed results in studies regarding fracture risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glitazones like rosiglitazone and pioglitazone are associated with following adverse effects:

 

  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Retention of sodium and water
  • Risk of osteoporotic fractures

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors like canagliflozin is also associated with increased risk of fractures but the incidence is much lower than that with glitazones.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zika Virus

 

The image shows transplacental transmission of Zika virus given causing microcephaly.

 

Zika virus crosses the placental barrier and the developing blood–brain barrier (BBB). ZIKV exhibits clear tropism for proliferative neural cells, often with cytotoxic effects. ZIKV also productively and detrimentally infects cranial neural crest cells (CNCC), which give rise to cranial bones and can exert paracrine effects on the developing brain. Once Zika virions enter neurogenic regions in the brain, they reduce the number of mitotic progenitor cells by promoting cell cycle arrest and apoptotic cell death, autophagy, or possibly by precocious differentiation resulting in microcephaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus primarily causes encephalitis and respiratory illness but does not typically cause congenital infections or microcephaly.

 

Option C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV can cause congenital infections and microcephaly, but the image and description provided are specific to Zika virus.

 

Option D. Rubella: Rubella virus can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which includes microcephaly among other defects, but the specific viral transmission and pathology detailed in the image refer to Zika virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Zika virus is known for causing microcephaly through transplacental transmission by infecting and damaging neural progenitor cells in the developing fetal brain.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S phase

 

Explanation:

 

S phase of the cell cycle is considered the most radioresistant. During the S phase, cells are actively duplicating their DNA. The replication machinery during this phase makes the DNA less accessible to radiation-induced damage and the cell has enhanced mechanisms to repair any damage that does occur, thereby making it more resistant to the effects of radiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M phase: The mitotic phase where cells are actively dividing. This phase and G2 are often considered more radiosensitive because cells are highly vulnerable to damage during mitosis.

 

Option C. G1 phase: The first gap phase where cells grow and prepare to synthesize DNA. This phase is relatively more radiosensitive compared to the S phase.

 

Option D. G2 phase: The second gap phase right before mitosis where cells prepare to divide. This phase is typically more radiosensitive, as cells are preparing for mitosis and have less capability for DNA repair compared to the S phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

S phase is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a study that is longitudinal, observational, and includes the analysis of variables to determine associations? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

Explanation:

 

  • The correct term for a longitudinal, observational study that involves the analysis of variables to determine associations among a group of people is a "cohort study”.
  • In a cohort study, participants are followed over time to see how different exposures affect their chances of developing an outcome. 
  • It's useful for studying the effects of suspected risk factors that cannot be controlled experimentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-Control Study: This type of study involves identifying participants based on the presence (case) or absence (control) of a particular outcome or disease and then looking back retrospectively to compare exposure to a risk factor or intervention between the groups.

 

Option C. Ecological Study: These studies assess risk factors or outcomes in a population based on data at the group level, rather than individual data. It's useful for initial, broad correlations between environmental or contextual factors and health outcomes.

 

Option D. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): This is an experimental study where participants are randomly assigned to either the group receiving the intervention or to a control group that does not, to compare outcomes in a controlled way.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For analyzing how various factors might affect health outcomes over time within a specified group, a cohort study is typically the most appropriate method due to its ability to follow participants through time and observe changes and outcomes as they occur naturally.

questions.text: The leading cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male children is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior urethral valve

 

This is the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants. PUV is a congenital malformation found only in boys where there is an abnormal fold of tissue in the posterior urethra, preventing normal urine outflow and leading to bladder outlet obstruction. The condition can lead to hydronephrosis if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethral atresia: This is a rare congenital anomaly where a segment of the urethra fails to canalize or develop. It leads to complete obstruction of the urethra, and while it does cause bladder outlet obstruction, it is less common than PUV in male children.

 

Option C. Anterior urethral valve: This is a rare congenital anomaly and is much less common than the posterior urethral valve. While it can cause obstruction, its prevalence and significance in causing bladder outlet obstruction in male children are far less than that of PUV.

 

Option D. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter within the bladder. It can cause obstruction of the ureter itself. They are not the leading cause in male children when compared to PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most frequent cause of bladder outflow obstruction in male children is the posterior urethral valve (PUV).
  • PUV is a membranous fold located in the posterior urethra, typically found just distal to the verumontanum. It is thought to occur due to the persistence of the urogenital membrane.
  • Urethral obstruction can cause dilation of the posterior urethral valve, bladder, and bilateral hydronephrosis, leading to a keyhole sign on prenatal ultrasound and potentially oligohydramnios.
  • If not detected prenatally, PUV may present postnatally as a newborn or young infant with urinary tract symptoms, abdominal distension or and recurrent UTIs.
  • Left untreated, PUV may result in chronic kidney disease, bladder dysfunction, and vesicoureteral reflux.
  • Diagnosis of PUV is typically based on the presence of an elongated posterior valve during the voiding phase of the voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of shoulder of a 25-year-old male who suffered a shoulder injury and now exhibits swelling around the shoulder joint. Based on the X-ray, which structure(s) is/are probable sites of injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament

 

  • The provided image indicates an upward displacement of the clavicle, accompanied by a noticeable gap between the clavicle and the acromion.
  • This suggests potential injuries to both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

 

ACROMIOCLAVICULAR JOINT DISLOCATION

 

  • Acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury typically occurs due to a fall onto the acromion.
  • Stability of the AC joint is dependent upon both the AC and coracoclavicular (CC) ligaments.
  • An acromioclavicular joint separation occurs when the clavicle separates from the scapula.
  • It is commonly caused by a fall directly on the ‘point’ of the shoulder or by a direct blow received in a contact sport.
  • AC Joint separation is almost always the result of a sudden, traumatic event that can be attributed to a specific incident or action.
  • The two most common causes are either a direct blow to the shoulder (seen in football, rugby, or hockey), or a fall on to an outstretched hand (after falling off a bicycle).
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain and swelling around the joint
    • Pain on movement of the arm
    • Depending on the grade, a bump may be present on the top of the shoulder where the clavicle ends
    • The joint may be very unstable
  • It is classified into type 1 to 6 by Rockwood classification according to the severity of the injury and position of the displaced bones.

 

 

 

 

  • Treatment according to the grades include:
    • Type I-III: Conservative management with velpeau bandage. The bandage pushes the lateral end of shoulder downwards and the arm upwards, thus maintaining the reduction.
    • Type IV-VI: Open reduction and internal fixation

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Coracoacromial ligament. Coracoacromial ligament originates from the medial border of the acromion and attaches to the lateral border of the coracoid process. This ligament forms a part of the coracoacromial arch and provides support to the humeral head. Coracoacromial ligament injury is mostly related to trauma or clavicular fracture and isolated injury to the coracoacromial ligament is rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acromioclavicular joint dislocation or separation, as shown in the image provided in the question, there is tear in the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presented with fever and retro-orbital pain for 2 days. The tourniquet test and NS1 antigen test were positive. Which of the following features is considered a criterion for the severe form of this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AST and ALT >1000

 

The clinical scenario of a 13-year-old girl with fever and retro-orbital pain, positive tourniquet test, and NS1 antigen test is indicative of dengue fever. A significantly elevated AST or ALT (≥1000) is a marker for severe dengue.

 

  • Dengue Fever Overview: Dengue is a viral infection transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. It presents with fever, myalgia, headache, retro-orbital pain, and a characteristic rash. The World Health Organization (WHO) has defined criteria for classifying dengue into probable dengue, dengue with warning signs, and severe dengue.
  • Criteria for Severe Dengue:
    • Severe plasma leakage leading to shock or respiratory distress.
    • Severe bleeding.
    • Severe organ involvement like elevated liver enzymes (AST or ALT ≥1000), CNS involvement, or cardiac dysfunction.
  • Elevated AST/ALT as a Criterion: High liver enzyme levels indicate severe hepatic involvement, which is a hallmark of severe dengue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leucopenia plus thrombocytopenia: Leucopenia and thrombocytopenia are common in dengue fever and indicate disease activity but are not specific criteria for severe dengue. Instead, they are considered warning signs.

 

Option C. Persistent vomiting: This is considered a warning sign in dengue fever. It suggests increased capillary permeability but does not alone signify severe dengue.

 

Option D. Hepatomegaly >1cm: While hepatomegaly is a sign of dengue, severe hepatomegaly (>2 cm) is more suggestive of progression towards severe disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AST or ALT levels ≥1000 are indicators of severe dengue and signify significant liver involvement, requiring close monitoring and possibly intensive care.

questions.text: The patient has a fever, cough, and cold. The chest X-ray is given below. What will be the examination finding in the infra-scapular region? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dull note on percussion

 

The patient's symptoms and the chest X-ray findings indicate pleural effusion. Key features of pleural effusion on a chest X-ray include the meniscus sign and blunting of the costophrenic angle. Clinically, pleural effusion leads to reduced or absent air entry in the affected area.

 

A dull note on percussion is a hallmark sign of pleural effusion. This occurs due to the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, which does not transmit sound vibrations as efficiently as air-filled lung tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperresonance on percussion: This finding is characteristic of pneumothorax, where there is an excess of air in the pleural space, leading to increased resonance.

 

Option B. Coarse crackles: Coarse crackles can be heard in various conditions such as bronchiectasis, the resolving phase of pneumonia, or pulmonary edema. However, they are not typically associated with pleural effusion.

 

Option D. Pleural rub: Pleural rub is a sign of pleuritis or inflammation of the pleura. It is usually absent in pleural effusion due to the separation of pleural surfaces by fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dull note on percussion is a key clinical finding in pleural effusion, indicating the presence of fluid in the pleural space.

choices.text: TPE removes the von Willebrand factor
TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

questions.text: Total plasma exchange is done in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. How does TPE help in the management of TTP? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is caused by a deficiency of ADAMTS13, usually due to autoantibodies. Total plasma exchange (TPE) removes these autoantibodies, thereby increasing ADAMTS13 protease activity and preventing the accumulation of large von Willebrand factor multimers. This results in platelet trapping. Classic clinical picture includes:

 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • End-organ damage (neurological injury)
  • Fever

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. TPE removes the von Willebrand factor: Incorrect; the goal is to remove autoantibodies.
 

Option B. TPE removes the antiplatelet antibodies: Incorrect; TTP involves anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies.
 

Option C. TPE replenishes the coagulation factors: Incorrect; TTP is not primarily a coagulation factor deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TPE in TTP primarily removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies, increasing ADAMTS13 activity and reducing microthrombi formation.

questions.text:
You are a primary care physician seeing a patient for a routine check-up. The patient expresses concern about colon cancer and asks about potential risk factors and preventive measures. You provide the following information: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Right and left colon cancers can exhibit distinct behaviour.
  2. Colon cancer can have hereditary components.
  3. Colon cancer risk can be mitigated by metformin.
  4. Liver metastases are a common occurrence in colon cancer.

 

Which of the following options is/are true regarding colon cancer:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4

 

All the 4 statements given are true about colon cancer.

 

  • Right and left colon cancers exhibit different characteristics, with left-sided tumors being more likely to cause obstruction due to the caliber of the bowel and consistency of stool.
  • Proximal colon cancers, or right colon cancers, are typically diagnosed later and may present with iron deficiency anemia or a mass.
  • While the majority of colorectal cancers occur sporadically, some can be hereditary and are more common in patients with a family history of the disease, like FAP and HNPCC. Genetic testing can aid in early diagnosis.
  • Metformin, a biguanide compound used to treat diabetes, has been shown to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer by disrupting cellular energy supply and inhibiting aerobic glycolysis.
  • Liver metastasis is the most frequent site of distant metastasis in colorectal cancer and occurs through hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. Tumor size and grade are risk factors. The second most common site of distant metastasis is the lung, while carcinomatosis can occur through peritoneal seeding.

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Complications specific to monochorionic twins are:

 

  • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS): This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels.
  • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion): This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction: While this can occur in monochorionic twins, it is not specific to them.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: This can be seen in various conditions and is not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Option D. Neural tube defects: These can occur in any pregnancy and are not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Thus, options A, B, and D are not specific complications of monochorionic twins.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg904,905

questions.text: During resuscitation in a patient with severe hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias, a patient received a 20% Intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Local anesthesia toxicity

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used as a treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). If a patient accidentally receives an excessive dose of local anesthetic, or if the local anesthetic is inadvertently injected into a blood vessel, it can lead to systemic toxicity, manifesting as CNS symptoms (like seizures) and cardiovascular collapse. Intralipid acts as a lipid sink, effectively reducing the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma and thereby reversing the toxic effects. This is why this option is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asphyxia due to drowning: While drowning can certainly lead to hypotension and arrhythmias, it does so because of hypoxia and other related complications. Intralipid injection is not a recognized treatment for drowning and its consequences.

 

Option C. Electrocution: While electrocution can cause cardiac arrhythmias and other cardiac problems, the primary treatment is to address the rhythm disturbances directly, treat burns, and support the patient. Intralipid would not be used in this context.

 

Option D. Pulseless electrical activity (PEA): PEA refers to a condition where there is organized or semi-organized electrical activity in the heart (seen on EKG) but no palpable pulse. The treatment for PEA is high-quality CPR, following the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm, and addressing any potential reversible causes. Intralipid is not a standard treatment for PEA.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used specifically for treating local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) by acting as a lipid sink to reduce the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 885

questions.text: A patient presents with perioral numbness, tingling, and tetany. All the following conditions can lead to this, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D toxicity

 

Vitamin D toxicity leads to hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia. Excessive vitamin D increases calcium absorption from the gastrointestinal tract and mobilizes calcium from bones, leading to elevated serum calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Perioral numbness, tingling, and tetany are symptoms indicative of hypocalcemia. Various conditions can lead to hypocalcemia, each through different mechanisms:

 

Option B. Acute Pancreatitis: This condition can lead to hypocalcemia due to the sequestration of calcium in the inflamed pancreatic tissue and the formation of calcium soaps.

 

Option C. Chronic Kidney Disease: CKD results in hypocalcemia primarily due to decreased production of calcitriol (active vitamin D). The kidneys are unable to convert 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, leading to decreased calcium absorption in the gut.

 

Option D. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition, often resulting from surgical removal or damage to the parathyroid glands, leads to decreased production of parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH is crucial for calcium homeostasis, and its deficiency results in hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D toxicity causes hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, distinguishing it from other conditions that can lead to hypocalcemia.

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports - Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythropoietin levels

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Erythropoietin levels should be determined to differentiate primary from secondary forms.

 

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis), but it is the increase in red cells (polycythemia) that is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms. PCV must be differentiated from relative polycythemia resulting from hemoconcentration and other causes of absolute polycythemia. PCV is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

In PCV the progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling. Accordingly, serum erythropoietin levels in PCV are very low, whereas secondary forms of absolute polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Philadelphia chromosome: The Philadelphia chromosome is associated with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) and would not be the primary investigation in a case where polycythemia is suspected.

 

Option B. JAK mutation: While JAK2 mutations are common in Polycythemia Vera, erythropoietin levels should be assessed first to differentiate between primary and secondary causes. If primary polycythemia is suspected after assessing erythropoietin levels, testing for JAK2 mutations would be the next step.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain: This test would be more relevant if there is a need to assess bone marrow fibrosis or other marrow abnormalities, but it is not the first-line investigation in the context of suspected polycythemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected polycythemia, particularly in patients from high-altitude areas, erythropoietin levels should be assessed first to differentiate between primary and secondary causes of polycythemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, Page No.  1161, 1242

questions.text: All are used in recombinant DNA technology (genetic engineering) except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isomerases

 

Isomerases are not used in recombinant DNA technology. Isomerases are enzymes that catalyze structural rearrangements within a molecule, converting one isomer to another. They don't have applications in genetic engineering techniques where cutting, joining, or modifying DNA sequences is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatases: These are used in recombinant DNA technology. Alkaline phosphatase removes terminal phosphate groups from DNA, which is useful in preventing unwanted ligation reactions in DNA cloning.

 

Option B. CRISPR Cas9:
 

CRISPR/CAS 9 System:

  • Causes double strand break
  • CROSPR- Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats
  • Cas-9: CRISPR associated endonuclease
    • This endonuclease is guided by CRISPR for cutting site
  • It is an immune system in bacteria against bacteriophages
    • Memory of bacteriophage infection and immunity is transferred to future generation also. So protect may future generations from viruses

Uses

  • Can be adopted to be used in eukaryotes for purposes like
    • Gene deletion
    • Exogenous gene insertion
    • Multigene editing possible
    • Altering gene transcription and regulation 

 

Option D. Terminal transferase: This enzyme is used in recombinant DNA technology to add nucleotides to the 3' OH end of DNA, which is useful in various molecular biology applications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isomerases, which catalyze structural rearrangements within molecules, are not used in recombinant DNA technology or genetic engineering, while phosphatases, CRISPR Cas9, and terminal transferase are utilized in these techniques.

questions.text: Fingerprint develops in how many weeks of intrauterine life? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 12-16

 

Fingerprints begin to form between 12 to 16 weeks of intrauterine life. By this stage, the basic patterns of the ridges on the skin are established. The formation continues, and fingerprints are complete by approximately 24 weeks of intrauterine life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fingerprints start developing between 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life and are completed by 24 weeks, providing a unique identification for the individual that remains unchanged throughout their life.
